pubinfo.pubplace: NOAA Coastal Services Center, Charleston, SC
NOAA Coastal Services Center, Charleston, SC

descript.abstract: Wai'anae R-Factor The Nonpoint Source Pollution and Erosion Comparison Tool (N-SPECT) was developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Coastal Services Center to accompany the Wai'anae Ecological Characterization being developed by the Hawaii Coastal Zone Management (CZM) program. N-SPECT examines the relationship between land cover, nonpoint source pollution, and erosion. N-SPECT is an extension to Environmental Systems Research Institutes (ESRI) ArcGIS software package, version 8.3 and requires the Spatial Analyst extension. N-SPECT is designed to be portable to any watershed, provided the user has access to the necessary data. Data provided with N-SPECT are for the Wai'anae ahupua'a, the original study area located on the western side of Oahu, Hawaii. The Wai'anae ahupua'a is the collection of catchments that drain the Wai'anae mountains westward to the Wai'anae coast (west coast of Oahu, HI), including Kaluakauila, Makua, Keaau, Makaha, Kaupuni, Kamaileunu, Mailiili, Ulehawa, and Nanakuli. The R-Factor data file is a grid that represents rainfall/runoff erosivity factors for the Wai'anae study region. R-values are plotted on maps with isoerodent lines that connect points of equal rainfall erosivity. The R factor values for Hawai’i are based on Dr. Andrew Lo's dissertation at the University of Hawai’i.
descript.purpose: This data set was digitized for use in N-SPECT. N-SPECT requires the input of a rainfall factor grid if the selected precipitation scenario is an annual precipitation scenario. The rainfall/runoff erosivity factor quantifies the effects of raindrop impact and reflects the amount and rate of runoff associated with the rain.

idinfo.useconst: Data set is not for use in litigation. idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.3.0.800

dataqual.logic: Tests for logical consistency indicate that all row and column positions in the selected latitude/longitude window contain data. Attribute files appear to be logically consistent.
dataqual.complete: The R-factor grid was generated to reflect as closely as possible the original isoerodent map. Each isoerodent line was digitized exactly as it appeared on the physical map, and the gridding process was performed to maintain the original quality of the data.

citeinfo.origin: USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service, Hawaii State Office, Honolulu, HI
citeinfo.title: Island of Oahu R Factor Map

srcinfo.srccontr: R-values were plotted on a map with isoerodent lines that connect points of equal rainfall erosivity. The .pdf form of the map provided a spatial layout of r-values from which a digitized version could be produced.

procstep.procdesc: The first step was to create a line shapefile that approximates, as closely as possible, the features of the R-factor map. Each of the line features was attributed according to the values given on the hardcopy map. Then, a one mile buffer was placed along the outside of the Oahu boundary shapefile. This was done to ensure full coverage of the entire island once the interpolation process is completed. The Geoprocessing Wizard was used to union the buffer shapefile and the R factor shapefile. The line features were converted to points using an ArcView 3.x script (pline2pt.ave). Arc ToolBox® was used to convert the point shapefile to a coverage, then clean and build the coverage. Using ArcGIS® and the Spatial Analyst extension, a grid surface based on the point coverage was interpolated. For our purposes, the kriging method was used with the R-factor attribute specified as the Z value field.

cntinfo.hours: Monday to Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Eastern Standard Time.

enttyp.enttypd: R quantifies the effects of raindrop impact and reflects the amount and rate of runoff associated with the rain. R is an average annual total of E, or energy component, multiplied by I, or the intensity that reflects the prolonged peak rates of detachment and runoff.
enttyp.enttypds: USDA, NRCS. 1998. Field Office Technical Guide, Section I, RUSLE.

attr.attrdef: Number of pixels with same value
